question: Buddd-dee! My God, if it ain't Buddy! Well, if this ain't the darnest thing!
answer: Excuse me... your voice is familiar and I'm sure I know you from somewhere...

question: Awww-rr, Buddy, come on, you know me!
answer: Well, I... I... ah-h, let's see...

question: It's Dave Wilkie! I'm Dave Wilkie, don't you remember me?
answer: Oh. Oh, God. Of course, Dave, how are you?

question: Well, I am in the construction business, Buddy, and without braggin' I have done real good at it. There are those who wouldn't have expected that out of me. Right now I'm buildin' a giant motel unit near Alexandria, outside Washington, D.C. Not fi-nance, I'm on the construction side.
answer: Well, that's interesting, Dave. I always liked Washington, it's a pretty town.

question: Oh, it's all right, beats Jew York. But the niggers have took it over, just like every other city we got, only worse. But I have done real good in the construction field. What I don't know about buildin' ain't worth knowin'. I knocked off twenty-eight thousand smackeroos last year, how's that for an old country boy? Ha ha, course you make a lot more. What's that you got there, Buddy?
answer: Galley proof.

question: Galley what?
answer: Page proof of a book I'm working on.

question: How about that. Well, you always were a screwball.
answer: Oh, yeah?

question: I don't mean that the way it sounds. Imagine it, a book. And I used to know you personal way back when. Tell me something, Buddy, how do you dream up all that stuff?
answer: Well, actually, we have a little black boy named Her---t who lives in the garage. He does it for me.

question: Heh heh heh heh, same old Buddy, always jokin' around. Almost as much of a joker as your Daddy. I saw your Daddy a coupla years ago, I was up in Glenville lookin' at a motel site. I guess that's where you're headed, huh, to see him?
answer: That's right, Dave, I'm headed for Glenville on a whisperin' jet.

question: Hey, girl! Hey, you, give us another drink! Dumb little bitch, supposed to give us two in the first place. This friggin' airline's out of its mind. The sons of bitches tried to put me in tourist. But our whole civilization is screwed up, Buddy. The heebies and the coconuts have took it over and ruined it. Took your time gettin' here.
answer: She has other things to do, Dave.

question: Supposed to get two drinks in the first place. This friggin' airline can't do nothin' right.
answer: Tell me about that job in Alexandria, Dave, the big motel you're building.

question: Near Alexandria. It isn't in Alexandria, it is outside it.
answer: I see. Outside it.

question: That's correct -- outside it, not in it. As for the job, well, the Jewboy suppliers give me a lot of grief and we use a pile of niggers to haul and tote and they ain't worth a sorry-ass damn. But I can build anything, Buddy. Give me the plans and I can build a goddamn staircase to the moon. It's a fact, I can build anything... ... but she never believed that. Oh, hell, no, she never believed in me.
answer: Um-m, well...

question: Doubted my ability all along, the little bitch. I never remarried, Buddy, you know that, don't you?
answer: Well, no, I didn't actually.

question: She's te reason -- cured me of women once and for all. Oh, I got rid of her, Buddy, I didn't waste no time kickin' that bitch out. Hell, she was screwin' everybody in Savannah. I caught her in a motel with this long tall son of a bitch and boy did I beat the everlastin' piss out of him! She didn't marry him, though, later she married another guy and went to Winston-Salem. It didn't last That girl couldn't have no lastin' marriage, she left him and married another dumb sucker and went out west. Little bitch left him, too, and you know what she's married to right now? A kike. That's right, some kind of kike horse doctor named Schapiro out in Seattle, who's got the nerve to have the same first name I got. Wouldn't you know it, Rose would wind up married to a goddamn kike? She was always out of her friggin' head and I'll tell you why. Buddy, she was sick in her mind and between her legs, too. She was a nymphomaniac.
answer: Dave, you are as full of shit as a Christmas turkey and you know it. Now if you want to start a fight on this plane and get yourself in jail, go right ahead. But I am telling you, you are full of shit right up to your eyeballs.

question: I don't want to start no fight with you, Buddy. Why do you say I'm full of shit?
answer: Dave Schapiro is no horse doctor and Rose has been a good wife to him for a long time. To call her a nymphomaniac is the most stupid thing I ever heard in my life.

question: You loved her, didn't you. Well, so did I. You'll have to admit she had four husbands.
answer: Yeah, it took her a while to grow up and find Mr. Right, but she did it. She found him.

question: She used to call me Mr. Right. Remember that, Buddy?
answer: Yeah, I remember it.

question: Well, I tell you, I don't know what the world's come to these days. Things used to be better. We didn't have any money, but things were better. Goddamn niggers and kikes burning the flag, rioting, raising hell -- they ought to shoot their asses off. I tell you, Buddy, where this country made its mistake was allowing people without property to vote. Well, got to get a plane to Savannah. Great running into you, Buddy. Give my best to your Daddy.
answer: Yeah, I'll do that, Dave.

question: Ah-h, if you happen to run into Rose sometime... do me a favor, give her a message for me, will you?
answer: Dave, I haven't seen Rose for years.

question: Buddy, I'm a sick man. I had a heart attack last year, I wasn't expected to live. You might see her. She writes your Daddy, and she and that doctor came to see him, didn't they? I wish you'd tell her something... I never could write letters.
answer: What do you want me to tell her, Dave?

question: Oh, to hell with it, never mind. Don't tell her anything. Don't even tell her you saw me. Got to run, Buddy, I'll miss my plane.
answer: He still loves her. The poor damn fool still loves her. A girl named Rose. Still take R75 to Glenville?

question: Hello. I'm Rose, and I've come to live with you and your family. What's your name? What do they call you?
answer: Lots of things. Buddy, mostly.

question: Buddy. Well, now, that's a nice name, I like it. I am real pleased to meet you. Hey, look, do you think you got a cold drink of ice water somewhere?
answer: Sure. Let me take your suitcase.

question: You're sweet.
answer: The new girl is here.

question: The new girl is here.
answer: Wonderful. What's she like, Brother? What is your impression of her?

question: She talks a great deal and smiles a lot. She's very pretty, she has a real good figure. She's very girlish or womanish, if you know what I mean. She wouldn't hurt anybody, this girl. She couldn't.
answer: Your impression is very reassuring, Brother. Of course she's had troubles, poor thing, but I sensed that was that the girl was like and I'm glad to have it reconfirmed.

question: You mean confirmed, Mother. I didn't confirm it before. I would have had to confirm it previously, in order for it to be reconfirmed.
answer: All right, all right. Doll and Waski are upstairs taking their nap, you go get them and bring them down to the living room. Where is the girl?

question: In the kitchen drinking all the ice water in Glenville. She walked out here, she didn't go by the hotel.
answer: Walked, in all that heat? It's a wonder she hasn't got sunstroke. I'll phone Daddy and you go get Doll Baby and Waski. Rose, this is Waski. His real name is Warren but we call him Waski. He doesn't like it much and I suppose someday we'll have to stop calling him that.

question: Walked, in all that heat? It's a wonder she hasn't got sunstroke. I'll phone Daddy and you go get Doll Baby and Waski. Rose, this is Waski. His real name is Warren but we call him Waski. He doesn't like it much and I suppose someday we'll have to stop calling him that.
answer: You can stop it right now.

question: When he was baby we called him "Wa Wa," a baby name, you know. You will find him a very good boy. His brother can be bad and so can his sister, but Waski is a very good boy. And as you can see he's beautiful.
answer: Oh, Mother, cut it out.

question: Well, well, well. So Miss Rosebud has arrived. Un-hmm. And you're all assembled here. Yes, indeed. Un hmmm. Well, Rosebud, now you are here, darling, and I swear to God graceful as the capital letter S. You will adorn our house, Rosebud, you will give a glow and a shine to these old walls. If there's one thing I like to have around, it's a frizzy-haired blonde. Now I assume Mrs. Hillyer and the children have introduced themselves and made your acquaintance, and so forth and so on?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: All right. Now as head of this household I have a couple of remarks to make. It is my dear wife's belief, which I accept although I do not totally grasp it, that to hire a person to do household work is a criminal practice. Therefore, you are here not as a servant, you are here as a friend, as a guest and hopefully as a member of this family. You will eat your meals with us, you will share life itself with us -- in love and harmony, dear Rosebud, in love and harmony. Do you understand me?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Now, I know you've had some troubles in your life, those... scoundrels in Birmingham and so forth trying to... lead you astray. I hope you find a safe haven here, honey, I know you've had a hard time. Life can be cruel to a young girl all alone. We welcome you to our home, Rosebud, we all welcome you from the heart and hope you are happy here.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Rose, who were those scoundrels in Birmingham?
answer: Nobody.

question: But who were they?
answer: They were just bad men, that's all.

question: In what sense were they bad?
answer: Bad is bad, Buddy. There ain't no sense to it.

question: Did they try to induce you to become a prostitute?
answer: I don't answer talk like that, Buddy. I just don't hear it, I turn my back and look away.

question: Was that what they tried to do? Was that why Daddy gave you the job, to save you from those scoundrels?
answer: Your Daddy is a wonderful man, I'll say that. He's the best and most kind-hearted man in the world.

question: Hey, Rose, did you hear about that terrible thing down in Cave Springs?
answer: What terrible thing in Cave Springs?

question: There was this old man that ate his niece.
answer: I didn't hear you. I didn't hear that.

question: He really did, he ate his little niece. He made pork chops out of her.
answer: I don't hear you. I just turn my back on that kind of talk and look away.

question: Well, it's only the truth. There are horrible things in the world, Rose.
answer: Buddy, you are in one of your evil moods, I don't want to talk to you. I'm going out and sweep the patio.

question: What are you studying now, Mrs. Hillyer?
answer: More history, Rose.

question: Are you going to get your degree soon?
answer: Well, I am working on my thesis.

question: It must be wonderful to be so smart. I don't see how you do it, reading all those books, learning all that stuff.
answer: Rose, you work too hard. Why don't you go sit down somewhere and drink a Co-Cola?

question: You're so sweet.
answer: Really, why don't you go sit down somewhere?

question: I like to work. I don't mind work. It's the least I can do after all you and Mr. Hillyer have done for me. You're so sweet. There never was nobody like you.
answer: Well, you run on now.

question: Good morning, sweetheart. Beautiful day.
answer: Yes, it's so nice I thought I'd work outside.

question: How goes it, darlin'?
answer: Slow, hon. But at least I can concentrate now that Rose is here.

question: What do you think of her, honey? Turn up your hearing aid.
answer: What?

question: Your hearing aid, it's buzzing at me like a snake.
answer: Oh. Did you say something?

question: I asked you what you think of Rosebud, now that she's been here a while.
answer: Honey, she's perfect. She works all the time and she's wonderful with the children. And they love her, even Brother likes her though he won't admit it. I think she's just perfect.

question: Um-hmm. Almost too perfect.
answer: And she's such a good-hearted thing, there isn't an ounce of harm or malice in her.

question: Well, I'll admit I don't see any flies on her yet.
answer: There are no flies on Rose, I don't know what you're talking about.

question: Well, let's hope for the best, darlin'.
answer: Hope for the best? I don't understand all this skepticism. I thought you liked Rose.

question: I love Rosebud, I am wild about Rosebud. I just hope she doesn't turn out to be a hidden hotcha character, that's all. We have growing children in the house.
answer: Hotcha character. If I had to live with your cynicism, I wouldn't want to live at all. What you can't understand is that the creative forces of the universe are positive, not negative.

question: All right, darlin', don't go off into the fourth dimension.
answer: I'm not in the fourth dimension -- -- you are in the fourth dimension, when you allow skepticism and doubt to take control. As Blake said, if God had doubt the sun would go out.

question: Forgive my crudity, darlin'. I don't understand these deeper things the way you do.
answer: Be nice to Rose. She's never had a real home.

question: Yeah, I know.
answer: Oh, Waski, you don't know anything.

question: I do, too!
answer: All right, what do you know?

question: Ehh, Lord, should have bought that stock when we had some money. A thousand millionaires.
answer: Oh, oh! Oh, Mr. Hillyer, I love you, I love you so much! I've tried, but I can't help it! Please kiss me -- will you kiss me?

question: Ahh-hem! Now, Rose, get off my lap. What are you doing, girl? Are you crazy?
answer: Yes, crazy about you! Kiss me, Mr. Hillyer!

question: Why, I'm not going to kiss you, you crazy girl. Now I'm telling you again, get off my lap. Come on, Rose, get up. Now you get up, I say, and stop this!
answer: No, no! You don't understand, I love you! It's real love and I can't help it! Please kiss me, Mr. Hillyer, I love you, I love you so much...

question: All right, all right. Now calm down, Rose, the children will hear you. Calm down, let's talk... about this thing, let's discuss it.
answer: Don't make me... me... me... get up!

question: I can't see. What are they doing, what's happening?
answer: They're discussing it.

question: I can't see, let me see...
answer: This is my place and you can't have it.

question: Ohhh-hh... what's happening now?
answer: He's trying to get up -- good God, one of her titties is out!

question: Wow! Brrrother!
answer: What are they doing?

question: Buddy, this is amazing, you wouldn't believe it.
answer: What are they doing, Doll?

question: He kissed her.
answer: Is that all?

question: He had his hand on her titty.
answer: Let me look. Aww-rr...

question: Thermopylae. The Persians shall not pass.
answer: Buddy... are you asleep?

question: No, I'm awake. What's the matter?
answer: Buddy, I am wandering in a wilderness, lost. I just feel awful. Do you mind if I get in bed with you for a little while?

question: Well, all right.
answer: I thought I'd go crazy back there in that room all by myself with nobody to talk to. As a child, I never had no room all to myself, we were awful poor. Buddy... I have got a confession to make.

question: What is it, Rose?
answer: It's so terrible I can't tell you. Oh, Buddy, you don't know how it hurts to have a broken heart, what a terrible feeling it is, and I've had a broken heart so many times. Men, I don't understand them, I can't figure them out and they break my heart, that's all. I can't find Mr. Right, Buddy, I can't find him no matter how hard I look, all I find is a whole pile of Mr. Wrongs. But this is the worst ever because it wasn't his fault. It was my fault, oh yes, my fault, I was bad -- oh God, I was bad, you wouldn't believe how bad I was.

question: What'd you do, Rose?
answer: Buddy, I was horrible. I can't tell you who it was, but do you know what I did? I sat on his lap and got ahold of him and wiggled and wiggled my ass on him and was worse'n you could know, a child like you. Why, I let one of my tits fall out deliberate on purpose and practically smack him in the face with it and I let my dern skirt come up so he could see my drawers... But to get back serious to what I was sayin', it is not only, Buddy, the loss of him but my own bad behavior what bothers me so...

question: You were pretty bad, huh?
answer: Why, it has just made me ill, Buddy. I'm sick. I don't want to eat nothin', I don't, and me I got a good appetite, that ain't nat'ral for me. I'm ill.

question: But, Rose, what is the cause of it all?
answer: Promise not to tell Doll? -- or nobody? Buddy, it's your Daddy! I'm so much in love with him I am out of my mind!

question: But, Rose, how could such a thing as that happen?
answer: I fell madly in love with him when he called me Rosebud. You know that first day when I come and he said I looked graceful like a capital letter S and called me Rosebud? I fell madly in love with that man right then. But it's a lost love, Buddy. He's a good man and won't have nothin' to do with me.

question: Can I touch you here? Hmmm, it's soft. It's awful soft.
answer: What did you expect?

question: Well, I thought they were more like a cantaloupe.
answer: Ha ha ha, that's some idea, a cantaloupe.

question: There's some kind of gristle in it, though.
answer: Buddy, quit that, you're just a child, you're not supposed to be interested in such things.

question: Actually, I am, though.
answer: You know, that Daddy of yours is the funniest man, the things he says, you never know what's going to come out of his mouth next.

question: Can I put my hand inside your nightgown, Rose?
answer: No, you can't. And I'll tell you this -- he scares me. As kind as he is, he scares me. You can't fool around with him, not with that man. And, boy, I sure better not try nothin' like that with him again, he'll fire me.

question: Rose, can't I see what the nipple on it is like?
answer: Buddy, what's come over you? A child like you, askin' such things.

question: But I'm curious, Rose.
answer: Buddy, get your hand offa me! Quit it, get you hand away...

question: Just for a second. Please, Rose, what's the harm?
answer: Buddy, you don't realize it but what you're doing isn't nice.

question: Aw, come on, Rose, I want to see what the nipple on it is like.
answer: You don' t need to know that. It's none of your business.

question: Well, are you satisfied now? Can we just lie and talk, huh?
answer: Hmmph. It has a nipple, all right.

question: 'Course it does.
answer: First I couldn't feel it, but now I feel it easily, it's like a little acorn.

question: All right, that's enough. You're just a child and wouldn't understand it, but that type of thing can stir a girl up. Now lie back and we'll talk.
answer: That was very interesting. Thank you, Rose.

question: Don't mention it.
answer: It was softer'n I thought, that was my main impression. You know, if you hit a girl there it would hurt her a lot.

question: Who would want to do such a thing as that?
answer: Well, some fiend might.

question: You know, Buddy, sometimes I can't figure you out at all. You can be very nice, but like your mother said there's an evil streak in you.
answer: There's an evil streak in everybody, Rose.

question: There ain't none in your Daddy. You know, what happened has just made me love him all the more. I not only love him, I respect him, I admire him.
answer: Rose, I have a serious favor to ask you.

question: Most men wouldn't do what he done. If they can get a girl they go right ahead and get her -- I guess to hell they do, just like a dern rabbit. 'Course later they'll tell her she's no good when they done the same thing their selves. They're a bunch of monkeys. I like 'em, but they're a bunch of monkeys.
answer: Rose, since you're here in bed with me and everything and I've already touched your titty...

question: Why, Buddy, shut your mouth! What an awful thing to say, and where did you get any such idea as that, anyhow?
answer: I'm curious to see what it's like. I'm very curious, Rose.

question: Well, now that is just too bad! Curiosity killed the cat.
answer: Yeah, but satisfaction brought him back. Can I?

question: No! You ought to be ashamed of yourself astin' such a nasty things a child your age!
answer: Can't I touch it a little, Rose -- not a lot, just a little?

question: Of course you can't! I'm... I'm shocked at you, Buddy, real shocked! Now you be quiet or I'm going back to my own bed!
answer: Please, Rose. I'm curious, that's all, I have a natural curiosity, it's only human. You're my friend, aren't you? Don't you like me? I like you, Rose, a lot -- in fact, I love you.

question: Well, you're sweet, but you don't really love me.
answer: Yes, I do. Please, Rose, be a good sport.

question: Buddy, you're just a child.
answer: I'm thirteen. And I have a natural curiosity. It's only nature, Rose, that's all. Now what's wrong with nature, huh?

question: You better quit that.
answer: But Rose...

question: I must be outta my mind. Buddy, quit it.
answer: Am I hurting you?

question: No. No, you're not hurting me. But I think you better quit it.
answer: But why, if I'm not hurting you?

question: Rose, are you all right? Are you sick or something?
answer: No. No, I'm all right. Oh, God, what have I done? I have robbed a cradle and fallen into hell! I must be crazy, a child like you. Oh, God, oh, Lord. This is awful, this is terrible, I gotta get outta here! Buddy, you wouldn't tell nobody, would you?

question: Don't worry, Rose, I won't tell a soul.
answer: I sure hope you don't. I gotta get outta here, good night.

question: Rose, what are you doing up?
answer: Nothin', just goin' to the bathroom.

question: Is anything wrong?
answer: No, sir.

question: Well, good night.
answer: Good night.

question: I hate to turn on this light, you Daddy's awake downstairs, but I have to take the chance. Buddy, please don't tell on me.
answer: I said I wouldn't.

question: Buddy, I have to ask you, as bad as I've been please have pity on me and don't ruin me by telling them what I did. I know it was bad, it was bad and dumb. But mostly it was dumb, I didn't mean you no harm, I'd never want to hurt a hair on your head and that's the truth. I love you. But they'd think I did, they'd think I was awful, they'd despise me and hate me...
answer: Well, I don't know what you're worried about. It was my idea, I was the one who thought of it, not you.

question: You don't understand. They'd blame me, not you. And they'd think I was awful, a disgustin' girl, which I am, but Buddy, please don't tell them. Please don't. Ill have to go and I love it here, I love your whole fam'ly, your Daddy, your Mother... Buddy, I know I'm no good, I'm a bad girl but I can't help it, please have pity on me and don't tell! Please don't, please...
answer: Rose, they could stick splinters under my fingernails, and I will never say a word! I will never tell them, because... I love you!

question: Brother, when I have to wake you up at eleven o'clock in the morning you're either sick or you were up very late last night. And you weren't reading Huckleberry Finn. I looked and its not in your room. Now what were you doing?
answer: Mother, I have to tell the truth. I wasn't reading Huckleberry Finn, I was reading one of those Little Dirty Comic Books.

question: Oh, Brother, I am so disappointed in you. You mustn't look at those horrible things, they degrade the human image. Sex isn't ugly, sex is one of the most beautiful things in life, the creative power of the universe is behind it. But we must respect that power, we must be in awe of it. I don't think you are sufficiently in awe of it. Get the castor oil. This isn't punishment, I don't believe in punishment. It's for your health. Obviously you're sick if you can act like that.
answer: Mother, cant you make it calomel instead of castor oil?

question: This is for your own good. When you look at negative, destructive things like those little filthy comic books, you are sick. Here, take this.
answer: Geccch, yehh, guhhhh!

question: Stop gagging like that and putting on a show, and swallow it.
answer: Uhhh, gahdam stuff!

question: What did you say, Brother?
answer: I said ahhh-dam stuff.

question: No, you didn't say that, Brother.
answer: Yes, I did, mother. Your hearing aid isn't working right. I said ahhh-dam stuff.

question: Quiet, you little muddy-eyed brat, or Ill kill you!
answer: Children, children! Be quiet, all of you! The vibrations in this house are strange today. Where's Rose, anyhow?

question: She's getting herself up to go out.
answer: What'd you say, Brother?

question: She's getting herself up to go out. I think she's coming down the hall now.
answer: Oh, yes, it's Thursday. Hello, Rose, dear... ... my, you're... looking pretty...

question: Oh, no, that's the style. It's meant to be clinging.
answer: Ye gods and little fishes. What have you done to yourself, Rose?

question: Nothin'. I got myself up, that's all.
answer: Got yourself up?

question: Yeah. I'm goin' out.
answer: Um-hmm. Well, that is the damndest outfit I ever saw in my life. You walk down the street like that and they'll put you in jail, Rose.

question: I'll take him with me downtown. And you, too, Rose, if you want a ride.
answer: Sure, love one. Here's your half-a cup of coffee.

question: That's a pretty stylish skirt, Rose. The only thing I don't understand is how did you ever get it on.
answer: Well, it has buttons.

question: How can the buttons stand the pressure?
answer: There are more on the other side.

question: Turn around, darlin'. They'll put her in jail. The damn little fool might as well be naked.
answer: Well, it is a little tight. But it isn't as bad as all that. No one will notice unless they have such thoughts in the first place.

question: Who doesn't have such thoughts? We'd better get going.
answer: You're not having lunch?

question: Just half-a-cup of coffee. I never eat, darlin', you know that. Not eating and reverse insomnia are my curses. Let's go, Rose, you and Brother, let's hit the road.
answer: Rose, you and Brother wait in the car. I want to speak for a moment Lo Mr. Hillyer.

question: I wish you wouldn't pick on Rose and tease her like that. Of course her clothes are silly, but she's ignorant, naive, she doesn't know any better.
answer: The girl worries me. If she walks down the street like that, an army will be following her.

question: Well, I admit that outfit isn't very modest. But she doesn't mean any harm, she just wants to attract, attention.
answer: She will succeed.

question: I don't think you understand her. It isn't sex she wants, it's love she wants and this is the only way she knows how to get it.
answer: That farmer in Gadsden was awful eager to get rid of her, and I'm beginning to see why.

question: He and his wife both said she had a fine moral character and was wonderful with children.
answer: Well, she loves children, all right. She loves everybody.

question: But that's a wonderful quality, not a bad quality. Have a little patience with her. She's such a good-hearted little thing and tries so hard.
answer: You are the one who's good-hearted. As for Rose, let's hope for the best.

question: Be kind to her. She loves you so much. In a perfectly proper way, of course.
answer: Yes, of course. What have you got in your hair, girl?

question: You were up late last night, Brother.
answer: Well, a little.

question: Reading dirty comic bocks. And you admitted it?
answer: Well, yeah.

question: I can't imagine why. It was just a thought. Where do you want me to let you out, Rose?
answer: Oh, anywhere downtown.

question: You don't know where you're going?
answer: Oh, I'll just mosey around here and there.

question: Is this ill right?
answer: It'll do just fine. Bye-bye, see you later.

question: Well, she's back.
answer: What time is it?

question: Quarter of twelve.
answer: Is she all right?

question: I don't see any bruises or broken bones.
answer: Bruises and broken bones, what kind of thing is that to say? Why shouldn't she go out and have boyfriends?

question: No reason at all, darlin'.
answer: Well, I wish you'd stop criticizing and picking on her.

question: Forgive my crudity, darlin'. All I'm saying is that a girl who would wear clothes like that is going to get in trouble sooner or later.
answer: Well, time will tell, won't it?

question: Chattanooga. I had St. Louis, Missouri.
answer: Buddy, I'm worried about Rose.

question: So am I.
answer: She hasn't got any sense. In some ways, she's awful dumb.

question: It isn't that she hasn't got any sense, Doll. Her basic intelligence is probably above average, maybe quite a bit above average.
answer: Then why does she act so dumb?

question: But I don't know who they are.
answer: Well, Rose, my sleep was a little disturbed last night, and so was Mrs. Hillyer's, and so was the children's. How about you? Was your sleep disturbed, too?

question: Yes, Mr. Hillyer, it was. I... I heard strange voices in the night.
answer: Strange voices, Rose?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Now Rose, stop behaving as if you're Bo Peep. Those men had a flight last night because of some female in this house, and it wasn't Dolly or Mrs. Hillyer.

question: Oh, shut up, Rose. Shut your mouth and quit crying!
answer: I will not sit here and listen to you be brutal to this poor girl.

question: I am not being brutal to her!
answer: You certainly are! She has an awful toothache, look at her jaw, it's all swollen.

question: Darlin', it is not my fault if the girl has epizootics -- -- I am not responsible for her epizootics and I did not bring about her epizootics. Now listen to me. When I have to get up in the middle of the night and defend my home with a shotgun against a couple of damned scoundrels fistfighting in the bushes --
answer: Scoundrels? They weren't scoundrels, they were just boys.

question: Boys? You say to me boys?
answer: Yes! Yes, I say that to you, they were boys! Boy friends of Rose, chat's what they were, and why shouldn't she have boy friends? Do you want her to be unnatural? Don't you think she's human the same way you are yourself? It's the South, that's what it is, the South with its horrible traditions, of slavery and crime and the oppression of women, who are just as good as men and just as human!

question: Now darlin', what has the South got to do with this?
answer: And when I try to talk to you seriously, when I try to explain to you the unlimited creative power of life, how beautiful it would be if we gave up this hopeless struggle and simply loved each other from our hearts, what do you do -- you mock me!

question: I don't intend to mock you, dear. I respect your philosophy. It's beyond my comprehension, but I respect it.
answer: Ohhh-hh, ohhh...

question: Oh, shut up, Rose, eat your cornflakes!
answer: I'm not hungry.

question: Now you listen to me, Rose --
answer: Just a moment! You are not going to fire this girl for an innocent thing like having boy friends, not while there is breath in my body!

question: I don't intend to fire her, darlin'.
answer: It isn't her fault if she's popular... what?

question: I said I don't intend to fire her. I just want to ask her to keep her boy friends away from my home and hearth, that's all.
answer: Well, that's very reasonable. Howe I hate to bring it up, but she's got an awful toothache, we've got to carry her to the dentist.

question: Look, you can't kid me.
answer: Now, come on, Rose. Stop being so childish, come on.

question: I'm not goin' in there, I don't like the looks of it!
answer: Rose, sit down in that chair and be quiet! We're trying to help you, you silly creature, sit in that chair!

question: You and the boy wait outside. Well, she finally let me look in her mouth. Is it true she's never been to a dentist?
answer: She was raised on a poor dirt farm. I'm sure she's never seen a dentist or hardly even a doctor.

question: Well, she has one mouth in ten thousand, I don't see teeth like that once in ten years. Her trouble is an impacted wisdom tooth, but there isn't a cavity in her head, not a single one. She has perfect teeth.
answer: But the wisdom tooth will have to be pulled?

question: Yes, and it's very bad. It probably should be done at the hospital under general anesthesia.
answer: That would scare her to death. She's terrified of hospitals. To her, a hospital is where you go to die.

question: Good morning, Rose. And how do you feel today?
answer: Wonderful. Except I can touch the place back there with my tongue, I wouldn't even know I had that tooth pulled.

question: Well, I know it, I just got the bill for it.
answer: Boy, for four or five days there I didn't think I'd live. But I'm my old self again!

question: Umm. Well. Yes. But no more strange voices in the night, Rose.
answer: Oh, no, sir.

question: Yes, ma'am.
answer: I see my mother-in-law's face, son. Read 'em and weep, boy, I am playing a spectacular combination, a triple. The nine ball in the corner! Read 'em and weep, boy, that's all she wrote. The Chief of Police? Rose is in jail. She bit a policeman's thumb. Come on, son, Shadrach can run the hotel. Yes, I know the son of a bitch. Well, Rose, what have you got to say for yourself?

question: I got an awful bad cold.
answer: That's all you've got to say, you've got a bad cold?

question: Well, I don't know what happened. They were arguin' about baseball, then all of 'em started fightin'. As for that policeman, I didn't bite him, I don't think I bit him.
answer: No, not really. But I guess we'll have to do that, John. Let her out. Let the crazy creature out and I'll take her home.

question: I got an awful cold, I think I'm sick. I didn't mean to bite him. He was hitting Horton with a blackjack in the meanest way and... and I bit him accidental.
answer: I have to go back to the hotel. I'm on duty at the desk and who knows a quest might arrive. I will see you at suppertime, Rose.

question: I didn't mean to bite him, I really didn't.
answer: I will see you at suppertime, Rose.

question: I'm sorry, darlin', I hate it as much as you do.
answer: Well, she does seem to cause a lot of trouble, I admit. But she doesn't mean any harm and it'll break the children's hearts, they all love her.

question: It's because of the children she's got to go. I don't want to be holier-than-thou, but the girl doesn't have the same outlook we do. Morals don't mean a thing to her, not a thing, and we can't have a girl like that in this house.
answer: Who is to say our morals are better than hers? But maybe you're right. She could... influence Dolly...

question: That is exactly what I'm afraid of. The girl has got to go, darlin'.
answer: But morals come from the heart, not from rigid rules and empty laws. And in her heart Rose has never hurt anyone and she never would. Therefore, she's not immoral. Not really.

question: Now look, darlin', this is no time to go off into the fourth dimension.
answer: But what I said is the simple truth. And now I see something else, I see more deeply into it...

question: How could Rose really be a bad influence on Dolly? She has a loving nature, you ought to want someone like that around your children. Why do you think those boys and men like her?
answer: Well, I have a pretty good idea.

question: If you mean sex, you couldn't be more wrong. Rose likes those boys and men, she has love in her heart, and that is what they want. It's the most rare and beautiful thing in life and that is why they follow her.
answer: They follow her because she's a -- -- no, I won't say that.

question: What she doesn't understand is that her behavior is disturbing to other people. She's young, she's got to learn to restrain the life force that's in her. Its creative, but in her case it's too creative.
answer: Darlin', Rose has got to go!

question: Well, Mrs. Hillyer, the girl is strong as an ox and that is what is keeping her alive. But not many people walk away from double pneumonia, Madam, not many.
answer: She looks terrible, just awful.

question: Of course she does and I must say I'm puzzled by your delay in getting her to the hospital. I should think ordinary powers of observation would have suggested to you that she was seriously ill.
answer: She hid it from us, Doctor. She's afraid of the hospital.

question: Afraid of the hospital?
answer: Deathly afraid of it. Her people were poor tenant farmers and she doesn't know anything about doctors or medicine or hospitals.

question: A tenant farm? Are you trying to tell me that girl is a product of the hookworm and pellagra belt?
answer: Well, her people were very poor. She says she was often hungry as a child, and I'm sure the food she ate was pretty awful, not a balanced diet at all.

question: Oh, he's so kind, so gentle inside, and so unhappy with that rich wife who doesn't understand him, her being a Southerner and everything, and what a bedside manner he has got -- so gentle and kind beneath the professor way he acts!
answer: Rose, you are too uncritical of people.

question: You don't know the bedside manner that man has got. Why, it does me good just to see him sit there all solemn and go pokin' in his bag like he's gonna cure me, which he did of course. And even more important he loves me, like a patient I mean, the other day he got tears in his eyes just listenin' to my heart beat.
answer: He did?

question: Yeah, he tried to hide it but I saw 'em, and a little bit he says to me, "You know, you are beautiful." Now wasn't that a nice thing for a doctor to say to a patient, wasn't it? What could cheer a girl up more?
answer: Rose, I have got doubts about that doctor and so does Daddy.

question: He's got doubts about hisself and that's the saddest thing of all. Would you believe that poor man thinks nobody likes him?
answer: Yeah, I'd believe it.

question: Well, I like him. I used to be afraid of doctors but not any more. Why, he could operate on me any old time and I wouldn't even be scared.
answer: Rose, you are just entirely too uncritical of people.

question: Sometimes the negativism and cynicism in you makes me want to vomit. Your real trouble is that you're anti-intellectual. The irony is women are supposed to be emotional, but I never saw anybody who depended more on emotion and prejudice than you do.
answer: Excuse me, gotta go to bathroom.

question: Now I have a plan about Rose, an educational plan. She's getting better and we don't want any more trouble -- Brother, you ought to hear this.
answer: I'll be right back.

question: You see, Rose? Now that's the kind of dress you ought to wear.
answer: Yeah, it's kinda nice.

question: You look very pretty in it, Rose. Really, you do.
answer: Well, you're real sweet to make it for me. There never was nobody like you. And you don't need to worry, I ain't goin' out no more.

question: Well, there's no reason you shouldn't go out, Rose... in moderation.
answer: I don't want to. When I was lyin' there in that hospital bed at death's door I says to myself, I ain't goin' out no more. If I ever get outta this, I'll just stay home. Besides, there ain't no Mr. Right out there. Or if there is I can't find him, all I find is a pile of Mr. Wrongs. I ain't goin' out no more. All right, we'll play monopoly then.

question: Um-hmm. Come with me, Brother. I want to show you something. See that, son? Now this is a heel, see, and there, that's the ball of a foot. Someone has been walking here.
answer: Well, it's not very plain.

question: That is because it rained recently, the rain has obscured the evidence. But you could still take plaster casts of these footprints, then match up the plaster casts with whosever shoes they are, and that way you could catch him -- understand?
answer: But how would you find him?

question: Well. Well, what I mean is, you could prove it was his shoes if you did catch him. But look this, Brother, it is even more interesting. Look at this mark here, and that mark over there. Now wouldn't you say those marks are the marks of a ladder?
answer: Well, I don't know. No, I don't know, Daddy, I think the rain has obscured it.

question: True, but if you look sharply you can see that those marks are the marks of a ladder. Now let's go back to the garage and see if the ladder has been tampered with. See, son? The paint is flaked off here, freshly. Look at it, Brother, there is no question about it. Some person or persons unknown have very recently tampered with this ladder.
answer: Well... maybe...

question: She's got somebody in there, Brother! His shoes are on the back porch -- there they were, naked and smiling at me! Rose, open this door immediately! Open up, Rose! Procrastination won't help you! All right, where is he? Where's the culprit? Where is he? I know he's in here, where is he, Rose? His shoes were on the back porch I smiling at met Where are you, you son of a bitch?
answer: There ain't nobody here, Mr. Hillyer! Honest, there ain't!

question: Where is he? Where have you got him hid? Ah, ha! And who, Rose, may I ask, is that?
answer: Well, it's Billy.

question: And what, may I ask, was Billy doing here?
answer: Well, Mr. Hillyer, Billy's very poor, he don't have no money and there wasn't no place else to go.

question: Well, it was a silly question.
answer: He's a nice boy, you'd like him. He wants to be a fireman.

question: Ye gods and little fishes, a fireman. Put on some clothes, Rose, you're naked as a jay bird. When you're dressed, come on downstairs. I'm afraid your friend Billy is injured, where are his clothes?
answer: Under the mattress. I hid 'em so you wouldn't be mad. He wants to marry me, he loves me. I can't marry him, he's too young and hasn't got no job, but he loves me... now you wouldn't hurt him, would you?

question: Well, I have got news! I called long distance and spoke to Cousin Hop and you'll be glad to know, Rose, I have found you a job!
answer: Tennessee?

question: Yes, Tennessee, a lovely state!
answer: Well. What kinda job is it?

question: Ahh-hh, you'll like it. It's a fine, outdoor-type job.
answer: You mean a farm?

question: No, no, not exactly. It isn't a farm in the sense that it's a farm. Not at all. It's a... dairy establishment. You'll 1ike it! I'm sure you'll like it because it's so... peaceful!
answer: Honey, Rose was born on a farm and has terrible memories of farm life. Now I don't think --

question: Just a minute, Rose, you don't understand. This isn't a dirt farm like the one you were born on, it's nice. A neighbor of Cousin Hop's, I talked to him on the phone, a fine man... it's not a farm, damn it, it's a beautiful dairy establishment! Stop crying, Rose! Do you hear me? Stop crying, it's ideal!
answer: I don't know how you can call it ideal -- don't you know what the word "farm" means to her?

question: I don't give a hoot in hell's hollow what it means to her! She can't stay in this house forever! I fired her, damn it!
answer: It sounds like a farm to me. Calling it a dairy establishment, that's just trickery and flummery.

question: What did you say, Rose?
answer: Well, I was born on a farm myself... and I hate to think of the baby being born on one.

question: What baby? What baby? What baby are you speaking about?
answer: Mine.

question: Your baby?
answer: Yes, mine. I'm going to have one.

question: I forgot that Rose will lie like a child. She's no more pregnant than I am, she just doesn't want to go to that farm!
answer: Yes, I am.

question: No, you're not.
answer: Yes, Mr. Hillyer, I am.

question: All right, tell us, Rose, what makes you think you're pregnant?
answer: I haven't had my period for three months and my stomach is getting big.

question: I don't believe it.
answer: It's so, Mr. Hillyer.

question: What's goin' on?
answer: Rose says she's goin' to have a baby and she sure looks it, but I don't think so.

question: A baby... and she isn't even married.
answer: That's the least of her troubles. Rose had a rare tropic disease and the little tubes in her that babies swim down are all stopped up, she told me all about it.

question: I'm not surprised you thought she was pregnant. An ovarian cyst can look very much like pregnancy. But it was pure wishful thinking on her part. The girl can never have children, she had gonorrhea at fifteen and it was untreated.
answer: Gonorrhea?

question: Don't worry, Madam, she can't infect your dear little kiddies. She long ago fully recovered, but the disease did irreparable damage. The girl is permanently barren.
answer: Well, that's pathetic. Poor Rose, what a life she has had.

question: We make our own lives, Madam. As for malignancy, I don't think so, it's very unlikely. I probably shouldn't have even mentioned that possibility to her.
answer: No, you shouldn't have, it was needlessly cruel. She thinks she has cancer and is going to die.

question: She's an adult, Mrs. Hillyer, I was merely giving her the facts.
answer: Well, it's a disaster. I don't know what to say, Doctor, I am floored. How dangerous is the operation?

question: Any major operation is dangerous. However, as we know from her previous illness, she's a very strong girl.
answer: Well, if it isn't malignant and she can get through the operation all right, it might be better than her really being pregnant. She doesn't even know who the father might have been.

question: I am thinking particularly of the other ovary. As a rule I don't believe in removing it. The woman's hormonal system is profoundly disturbed, she is subject to possibly serious depression, she loses many of her secondary sexual characteristics for example, her breasts might shrink and become flabby, facial hair might appear along with a coarsening of the features, and of course her sexual drive is greatly diminished, especially in a girl or young woman. For these reasons I am opposed to removing the other ovary, as a rule. Do you follow me?
answer: I am ahead of you.

question: Then... may I speak quite frankly with you, Mr. Hillyer?
answer: Please do.

question: I have of course observed the girl in treating her.
answer: Of course.

question: I think we both know her.
answer: Yes, we know her.

question: You'd go so far as to mutilate a helpless girl who has no means to defend herself, you'd go that far? Don't you think I know what you've just said and don't you think I understand the dreadful and revolting crime you've just conspired to commit? I thought I knew you. I thought I knew you better, I thought in your heart you were a good and kind man. Well, I can't believe what I've just heard in this room. A defenseless girl depending on you for protection, and you propose to mutilate and destroy her. How could you listen even for a moment to that sadistic man?
answer: Well, now, darlin'... give me a chance to defend myself.

question: I can't believe you really meant it, if I did I'd want to die. You aren't a male monster, that man is but you aren't. Look me in the eye and tell me, do you really want to take Rose's womanhood away from her when it's all she has got?
answer: Well, I... I hadn't thought about it that much. I was thinking... well, it's an idea, the girl is oversexed, and...

question: Rose isn't oversexed, that's ridiculous. If you're going to talk nonsense, I don't want to talk to you at all. Rose is exactly the same as the rest of us, except more so.
answer: Well, I know, more so. That's why I was thinking... maybe she'd be better off.

question: I will not cry like a woman. If I'm upset it's because of what my husband said, not because of you. You can't make me cry like a woman, a woman has got just as much intelligence and self-control as a man. And you get this in your head. If you hurt that girl, I'll hire lawyers and sue you for malpractice for every penny you have got, I'll do my level best to ruin you. Do you understand me?
answer: Yes, I understand you, but you have misunderstood me completely.

question: I understand you perfectly. You leave that girl alone, you wretched man, or you will be sorry.
answer: Actually of course I won't operate, I don't do major surgery. Dr. Hardy will operate and of course he'll be guided by your wishes in this respect.

question: Hi, Buddy. How's my sweetheart who never told on me when I was bad?
answer: Okay.

question: Makin' homes for purple martins, huh? We had 'em on the farm. They're the prettiest things. That's what I wish I was, a bird. Just fly around catch bugs and have a lot of fun.
answer: What are you going to do, Rose?

question: Take a little walk with me, huh? I guess I'll work as a waitress, Buddy. I done that before and it got me in worse trouble than you could know, but I can't stay here no more. Why did you get rid of your rabbits, Buddy?
answer: They're dumb things. I got tired of them.

question: Did you know when I was a child we had pretty near five hundred rabbits?
answer: Five hundred rabbits?

question: Yep, we had 'em in orange crates all over. It was Daddy's dream. He was goin' to get rich raisin' rabbits. It was what killed Daddy. He didn't drown hisself till a long time later after Momma and Lunette died of typhoid, but it was them rabbits what killed him.
answer: How did the rabbits kill him?

question: He thought he could sell 'em, but nobody but country folks eat rabbits, Buddy, and they ain't got no money. We had to eat them dern rabbits our own selves. Every dern one, and it took about four years to eat 'em all up.
answer: Well, that doctor said you got protein somewhere and I guess he was right.

question: Boy did I get sick of rabbit. But later on after Momma died and Daddy wasn't doin' nothin' but drinkin', I sure would of been glad for a little rabbit stew. You know, I oughtn't to of told you about what Daddy done when I was a child. Until them rabbits ruined him, he was a real good man, Buddy.
answer: What was your mother like?

question: A saint just like your own mother. She's up in heaven right now, her and Lunette, there ain't no doubt about it.
answer: Maybe it was eating all those rabbits that made you sexy, Rose.

question: Well, it isn't a picnic, honey. It's a barbecue.
answer: Okay.

question: A picnic doesn't involve roast meat, hon. At a barbecue you have a lot of roast meat.
answer: Well, all I know is there's ice cream. And I'm gonna have me a plate right now!

question: Well, you rascal, where'd you come from?
answer: Hello, Daddy. How are you?

question: About as good as can be expected with one foot in the grave. Good to see you, son. Did you bring any of that Yankee whisky with you?
answer: It isn't Yankee whisky, Daddy, it's Scotch.

question: I can use a drink after the plane ride I had.
answer: Your wife and children are back in New Hampshire in the snow?

question: Yeah, they're in the snow.
answer: Are they polar bears, too?

question: Good God, the way you live here. This place hasn't been dusted since Mother died. Look at that goddamned refrigerator.
answer: Got another twenty years in it, boy. By the way, son, do you recall Rose, that pretty blonde girl who came to our house way back in 1935 or 1936 and caused such a damnable commotion.

question: Of course I recall Rose. In fact I've been thinking of no one else for the last hour and a half.
answer: How could that be, son?

question: Dave Wilkie of all people was sitting by me on the plane -- her first husband. It's funny you would mention Rose. Did you hear from her?
answer: Well, yes, in a manner of speaking. You'll have the back bedroom, son, Mother's old art room. Just be careful going down the stairs you don't break your Yankee neck.
